title: The 15 Greenest Cities in America
text:
The 15 Greenest Cities in America Written by: Caroline Nolan 10/25/15 - 10:08 AM EDT 
October is National Energy Awareness Month, a national effort created in 1991 by President George H.W. Bush to highlight the importance of central energy to national prosperity, security, and environmental well-being. 
A survey by Pew Research found that 71% of Americans say the United States should do whatever it takes to protect the environment. 
"Individuals can go green by doing simple things,” says Albert H. Segars, faculty director of the Center for Sustainable Enterprise at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill’s Kenan-Flagler Business School. More Headlines 6 Empowering Halloween Costumes for Women 
When possible, walking or biking to a destination instead of driving a car is better for your health and helps to cut down on traffic. Additionally, using a thermos or water bottle, supporting local businesses, and taking advantage of local farmers markets are other great, simple ways to help the environment. 
Cities are also expected to make contributions toward sustainability, especially when they align to economic goals. "Green cities are better, healthier places to live,” says Ujjayant Chakravorty, professor of economics in the School of Arts and Sciences at Tufts University. “They increase property values and benefit residents, and by developing green practices such as renewables and urban gardens, they can connect residents with their immediate environment." 
So, which cities most encourage an environmentally friendly lifestyle? WalletHub has analyzed 100 cities across 13 key metrics, including greenhouse-gas emissions per capita, percentage of commuters who drive, the number of smart-energy policies and initiatives, and number of farmers markets per capita.
